[[Ali Azmat]] }} '''Junoon''' ([[Urdu]]: '''Ø¬ÙÙÙ''', literal English translation: "obsession/passion") is a [[sufi rock]] band from [[Lahore]], [[Punjab (Pakistani province)|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]], formed in 1990. The band is directed by founder, lead guitarist and songwriter, [[Salman Ahmad]], who was soon joined by keyboardist [[Nusrat Hussain]] and vocalist [[Ali Azmat]]. Junoon is Pakistan's most successful band; the ''[[Q magazine]]'' regarded them as "One of the biggest bands in the world" and ''[[The New York Times]]'' called Junoon "the [[U2]] of Pakistan".[http://magnatune.com/artists/junoon Junoon featuring Salman Ahmad: The U2 of the Muslim World] Retrieved on 30 May 2010 Since their inception, the group has released a collective total of seventeen albums: seven studio albums; one soundtrack; two live albums; four video albums; and three compilations. Junoon is also South Asia's most successful band of all time with more than 30 million albums sold worldwide.[http://www.elanthemag.com/index.php/site/blog_detail/salman_ahmad_talks_rock_and_roll_jihad_in_new_york_city-nid36060085/ Salman Ahmad Talks âRock and Roll Jihadâ in New York City] Retrieved on July 25, 2010. Pioneers of [[sufi rock]],[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rob-asghar/a-rock-and-roll-jihad-for_b_197234.html A Rock and Roll Jihad for the Soul of Pakistan]. ''[[Huffington Post]]''[http://pluralism.org/news/view/12262 The Pluralism Project at [[Harvard University]]: Salman Ahmed Brings Sufi-Rock, Political Message to Harvard (Massachusetts)] with such an original sound they achieved success during the early 1990s. Its members were signed to [[major record label]] [[EMI Records]] and afterwards released their self-titled debut album ''[[Junoon (Junoon album)|Junoon]]'' in 1991. After two years, the band recorded their second album ''[[Talaash]]'' (1993) with their new bassist [[Brian O'Connell (musician)|Brian O'Connell]] after [[Nusrat Hussain]] left the band. The release of their second album began to create a cult following for the band. In 1996, Junoon released their third album ''[[Inquilaab]]'', and it was only then that Junoon developed a nationwide fan following, with blending rock guitars and bluesy vocals with eastern elements like the use of [[tabla]]s, raga-inspired melodies, traditional [[folk music|Pakistani folk music]], and Eastern inspired poetry. The following year, the band recorded the critically acclaimed ''[[Azadi (album)|Azadi]]'' (1997), being the band's first international record deal, and making it Junoon's debut album in [[India]]. The band went on to record and release ''[[Parvaaz]]'' in 1999. The band found renewed success and popularity starting with 2001's ''[[Andaz (album)|Andaz]]'' and through 2003's ''[[Dewaar]]'' and their supporting tours. After the release of their seventh studio album, vocalist Ali Azmat and lead guitarist Salman Ahmad went on to pursue a career as a solo singer, while bassist Brian O' Connell returned to his native [[United States]].[http://nadeemfparacha.wordpress.com/2006/12/24/a-band-is-dead-long-live-music/ A band is dead. Long live music!'], Retrieved on 26 December 2006. Although Junoon's two other members, Ali Azmat and Brain O'Connell, left the band in 2005, Salman Ahmad continues to perform as a solo artist under the "Junoon" label and has moved to New York. In 2010, Junoon released the soundtrack album ''[[Rock & Roll Jihad]]'' based on Salman Ahmad and Junoon's musical journey throughout the years. ==History== ===Early years (1980â1989)=== Junoon's roots stretch back to [[Tappan, New York]], in the 1970s. [[Salman Ahmad]] left [[Lahore]], [[Pakistan]], for New York with his family when he was eleven, and received his baptism in [[rock music]] when a friend offered him a ticket to a [[Led Zeppelin]] concert. Salman Ahmad was so enthralled by the show that he saved $235 to buy his own [[electric guitar]]. He also befriended [[Brian O'Connell (musician)|Brian O'Connell]] in Tappan, another young aspiring musician, with whom Ahmad formed their first band together by the name of "Eclipse". Before the two friends could take their aspirations out of the basement and onto a bigger stage, Salman Ahmad's parents moved back to Pakistan in 1981, and Salman began to study medicine at Lahore's [[King Edward Medical College|King Edward's Medical College]].[http://www.musicianguide.com/biographies/1608003880/Junoon.html Junoon - Biography] Retrieved on May 30, 2010[http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/04/29/prof-rock-star-urges-muslim-students-in-queens-to-rock-out/#more-161771 âProf. Rock Starâ Urges Muslim Students in Queens to Rock Out] Retrieved on July 25, 2010 In 1987, [[Nusrat Hussain]], by then the lead guitarist of the band [[Vital Signs (band)|Vital Signs]], after composing the song "[[Dil Dil Pakistan]]" parted ways with Vital Signs and suggested [[Rohail Hyatt]], founder and keyboardist of Vital Signs, to bring [[Salman Ahmad]] as his replacement in the band. Vital Signs then went on to record their debut album at the [[EMI Studios]] in [[Karachi]], but almost all the songs were written and composed at Salman Ahmad's residence where the band had been lodged. In March 1989, the band released their debut album, ''[[Vital Signs 1]]'', which was a success throughout the country. The following year, Salman Ahmad parted ways with the most successful pop band of [[Pakistan]] as he wanted a change in the band's music for their second album and therefore after leaving the band he went on to form his own band.[http://www.chowk.com/articles/10653 Vital Signs: A Personal History] Retrieved on August 13, 2010 First, he recruited singer [[Ali Azmat]] from the [[Jupiters]] and then the former Vital Signs lead guitarist, Nusrat Hussain, on keyboards. ===Formation (1990â1993)=== [[File:Junoon-rehearse.jpg|thumb|right|250px| Junoon, during its early days, rehearsing before a concert. Visible from left to right are; Ustad Ashiq Ali Mir and [[Salman Ahmad]].]]Junoon formed in 1990 when Salman Ahmad, founder, songwriter and lead guitarist, had a dream where one of his teachers shook him and said "Tumhey mousiqui ka Junoon hai!" (You have an obsession for music!).[http://www.billboard.com/artist/junoon/bio/338514#/artist/junoon/bio/338514 Junoon Biography & Awards] Retrieved on May 18, 2009[http://www.junoon.com/articles/art_52_musicworld_may6.html Salman Ahmad â Interview] Retrieved on June 05, 2009 Junoon were not an over night success, the band members struggled for the first few years. Their self-titled debut album, ''[[Junoon (Junoon album)|Junoon]]'', recorded at the [[EMI Studios]] in [[Karachi]] barely made a dent in the [[Pakistani music]] industry when released in September 1991. After the release of their debut album, Nusrat Hussain parted ways with the band to pursue his own career as a solo singer and went on to release his debut solo album ''[[Amrit]]'' in 1992.[http://www.historyofpia.com/people62.htm Capt. Nusrat Hussain] Retrieved on July 27, 2010 After the departure of Nusrat Hussain, Salman Ahmad contacted [[Brian O'Connell (musician)|Brian O'Connell]] and invited him to play bass on the band's second album. Brian O'Connell quit his job as a social worker and traveled 10,000 miles to [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]], where he reunited with his old friend. It was after ten years both the friends reunited. In 1992, the band started working on their second [[studio album]]. The album was recorded and mixed at Tahir Gul Hasan's Sound On Sound recording studios in Karachi. While working on their second album at one side, on the other hand the band also featured in a television series, ''[[Talaash (TV series)|Talaash]]'', directed by [[Atiqa Odho]] and written by [[Anwar Maqsood]], based on the true story of the band in which the band members acted themselves and due to its novel storyline it became an extremely popular television series in Pakistan.[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZzFU3DMCqcE&feature=related Talaash PTV Show] Retrieved on July 24, 2010. The television series were aired on [[Pakistan Television Corporation|PTV]]. On September 23, 1993, Junoon released their second album ''[[Talaash]]'' which began to create a cult of a following for the band. Singles from the album, such as "[[Talaash (song)|Talaash]]", were politically influenced and became subject to censorship, which led to the eventual ban from all state run television and radio during the rule of by then the Pakistani Prime Minister, [[Nawaz Sharif]]. ===Rise to fame (1994â1997)=== In 1994, Junoon started working on their third studio album. In 1995, the band released their first compilation album, ''[[Kashmakash]]'', which is believed to be the very first compilation album by a band in [[Pakistan]]. Junoon were courted for the controversial video release of the single "[[Ehtesaab]]", from ''Kashmakash'', which included footage of a polo pony eating in a posh restaurant. Many thought that the image was an indictment of the corrupt [[Pakistan]]i political elite, and especially of former Prime Minister [[Benazir Bhutto]].[http://books.google.com.pk/books?id=F5_VlFyCIBgC&pg=PA149&lpg=PA149&dq=%22Ehtesaab%22+%28political+accountability%29#v=onepage&q=%22Ehtesaab%22%20%28political%20accountability%29&f=false Rock & Roll Jihad] Retrieved on July 22, 2010. The government quickly responded to it and banned the song and video from the state television. In 1996, the band released their third studio album, ''[[Inquilaab]]'', which was recorded and engineered with a completely new sound at Aamir Hasan Studios, ''[[Inquilaab]]'' was a blend of western music with classical eastern sufi music. It was the release of their third album when Junoon started to gain success and began to reach a wider audience when one of their singles, "[[Jazba-e-Junoon]]", became the signature song of the [[1996 Cricket World Cup|Cricket World Cup]]. [[File:Junoon-cdazadi.jpg|thumb|left|250px| Junoon's fourth studio album, ''[[Azadi (album)|Azadi]]'', hit platinum sales for which the band received a platinum certification. The album was a huge success in [[South Asia]], being Junoon's highest selling album.]] Following the success of their third album release, the following year Junoon went on their first full-scale tour of the [[United States]], performing from [[Birmingham, Alabama]], to [[Los Angeles]] where they appeared at the [[House of Blues]] and from there to [[Roosevelt Hotel (New York)|New York's Roosevelt Hotel]], which featured in ''[[Newsweek Magazine]]''. They also went on tour to [[Canada]] and the [[UAE]] through which Junoon's fame grew rapidly. In September 1997, Junoon released their fourth studio album, ''[[Azadi (album)|Azadi]]'', which was the band's first international record deal after the band manager, Shehryar Ahmad, secured a deal with [[EMI]]/[[Virgin Records]] and making it their debut album in [[India]]. Within three months of the release of ''Azadi'', the album had sold over half a million copies and hit platinum sales status in a record of four weeks.[http://www.screenindia.com/old/may08/music4.htm Junoon's album Azadi hits platinum in record time] Retrieved on April 1, 1998. The music video of the first single, "[[Sayonee]]", was shot by Asim Reza which became an instant hit in [[South Asia]] and the [[Middle East]], shooting to the top of all the Asian charts, and staying at #1 on both [[Channel V]] and [[MTV Asia]] for over two months. Later that year, Junoon went on their first Indian tour. The band's first concert was held in [[New Delhi]], [[India]]. After traveling throughout the country, Junoon saw crowds of as many as of 50,000 fans at different venues. The band was courted for a controversy during their tour to India by the Pakistani government. The Indian government was testing nuclear devices at that time, and [[Salman Ahmad]] suggested that the Indian and Pakistani leaders should spend more on education and health and less on weapons. This led to a prolonged ban on Junoon's music by the Pakistani government. [[Pakistan Television Corporation|PTV]], the Pakistan state television, refused to show the audience even clips from Junoon releases. The Ministry of Culture charged Junoon with making comments in India amounting to sedition and treason. The band members denied these charges, reminding people of the fact that they had been victimised since the release of "Ehtesaab" because they chose to speak out against political corruption.{{cite news | first=Salil | last=Subedi | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Songs of Freedom | date= 16 March 2001 | publisher=The Nepali Times | url =http://www.nepalitimes.com/issue/2001/03/16/Leisure/8290| work = | pages = | accessdate = 2001-03-16 | language = }} ===Success (1998â2000)=== {{listen | filename = Sayonee2.ogg | title = Sayonee | description = [[Sayonee]], Junoon's single from their fourth studio album ''[[Azadi (album)|Azadi]]''. The song is written by lead guitarist [[Salman Ahmad]] and lyricist Sabir Zafar. The single was a hit in [[South Asia]], topping all music charts in [[Pakistan]], [[India]] and [[Bangladesh]]. The success of the single led the album being the band's highest selling album in South Asia and Junoon received a platinum certification for hitting platinum sales for their album. Also, the single was nominated for the 'Best International Song' at the [[Channel V|Channel V Awards]] in 1998. | filename2 = Junoon-bulleya.ogg | title2 = Bulleya | description2 = [[Bulleya]], Junoon's single from their fifth studio album ''[[Parvaaz]]''. The single is a poetry by famous sufi poet [[Bulleh Shah]]. The single was a massive hit in both [[Pakistan]], [[Bangladesh]] and [[India]], topping many music charts. }} On February 28, 1998, Junoon won the "Best International Group" title at the [[Channel V|Channel V Music Awards]], where they performed along with world-wide icons [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[The Prodigy]] and [[Def Leppard]].{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A-LBNAGId8A| title=Junoon - V Award Ceremony 1998 Junoon Wins Best International Band Award|accessdate=July 16, 2010}}[http://www.rewaj.com/entertainment/junoon-to-perform-at-mtv-awards.html Junoon to perform at MTV Awards] Retrieved on April 19, 2011. ''Azadi'' was nominated for "Best International Album", having achieved the prestigious honour of being the highest selling album in [[Pakistan]], [[Bangladesh]] and [[India]] that year. In March, [[Zee TV]] invited Junoon to perform at the star-studded [[Zee Cine Awards]] in [[Mumbai]], where the group received accolades from the crÃ¨me de la crÃ¨me of India's entertainment industry.{{cite news | first=Namrata | last=Joshi | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Sound Invasion| date= April 27, 1998 | publisher=India Today | url =http://www.india-today.com/itoday/27041998/arts.html| work = | pages = | accessdate = 2010-06-16 | language = }} On August 9, Junoon performed at the [[Central Park]] in [[New York]], this concert was one of most famous concerts done by the band.{{cite news | first=Jon | last=Pareles | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Moving the Spirit (and Feet) With Ancient Utterances Updated| date= August 11, 1998 | publisher=The New York Times | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/11/arts/pop-review-moving-the-spirit-and-feet-with-ancient-utterances-updated.html| work = | pages = | accessdate = 2010-06-16 | language = }} Junoon then went on to perform at the [[BBC|BBC Mega Mela]], which is the largest South Asian festival outside of [[South Asia]], held in [[London]], [[England]]. Junoon performed at all three days of the Mela and performed at the [[BBC|BBC Asian Awards]] where they were also awarded for their "Contribution to Asian Culture".[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/527955.stm Culture awards at Asian festival] Retrieved on November 20, 1999. In March 1999, the [[Prime Minister of India]], [[Atal Bihari Vajpayee]], in a spirit of cross-border friendship, invited the band to perform at the anniversary of his government in Delhi. Travelling in the same gilded bus that Vajpayee had travelled cross-border to shake hands with Pakistan and sign the [[Lahore]] declaration, Junoon crossed the [[Wagah]] border from Lahore into India. In a very emotional performance before the Prime Minister, they performed the [[Jupiters]] hit, "Dosti" onstage with Indian group, [[Silk Route (band)|Silk Route]]. Later the same year, Junoon released their fifth studio album, ''[[Parvaaz]]'', which was recorded and mixed at [[Abbey Road Studios]] in [[London]] and was hailed by many critics as the finest work by Junoon to date and was released by [[EMI]] internationally and by Lips Records in Pakistan. The album was mostly based on the poetry of [[Bulleh Shah]] and singles from the album such as "[[Bulleya]]", "Sajna", "Ghoom" and "Mitti" were a success and did well at the music charts. The album was produced by John Alec who came from New York to work on the band's fifth studio album. Also in 1999, [[UNESCO]] invited Junoon to perform at their Millennium Peace concert held in [[Paris]], [[France]]. Junoon were presented with an award "Outstanding Achievements in Music and Peace" by UNESCO. The event was attended by many well known artists from around the world like [[Yesudas]],[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-79277039.html Unesco award for musician K.J. Yesudas] [[Lionel Richie]], [[Montserrat Caballe]] and [[Zubin Mehta]]. Famous actors like [[Gregory Peck]], [[Sidney Poitier]], and [[Peter Ustinov]] were also present at the concert. By the end of the year, Junoon toured to Bangladesh, where 45,000 ecstatic fans attended the concert at the [[Bangladesh Army Stadium]] in [[Dhaka]]. In 2000, Junoon released a compilation of their albums and videos, ''[[Millennium 1990-2000 (album)|Millennium 1990-2000]]'', through Lips Music Records. The compilation album consisted of singles like "Azadi", "Muk Gaye Nay" and live tracks like "Allah Hu". Later the same year, Junoon performed in [[Japan]]. On June 30, the band then went on to perform at the European Rock Festival, [[Roskilde Festival]], near [[Copenhagen]], in [[Denmark]].[http://www.roskilde-festival.dk/frontpage/history/2000/poster/ Roskilde Festival 2000 Poster] Retrieved on July 15, 2010. Junoon became the first Asian band to perform at the festival and performed along with many well known bands and musicians like [[Pearl Jam]], [[Iron Maiden]], [[The Cure]], [[QueensrÃ¿che]] and many other well known artists from around the world.[http://www.roskilde-festival.dk/frontpage/history/2000/bands/ Rosklide Festival 2000 Bands] Retrieved on July 15, 2010.[http://www.aural-innovations.com/issues/issue12/rosk2000.html Roskilde Festival 2000] Retrieved on April 30, 2011. At the end of the year, Junoon performed at a concert in [[Dubai]], [[UAE]], with [[Bollywood]] singer [[Sonu Nigam]], with nearly 20,000 in attendance, which was organised by [http://www.oberoievents.com Oberoi Middle East Events]. ===Continued success (2001â2004)=== In March 2001, Junoon released its sixth studio album, ''[[Andaz (album)|Andaz]]'' (titled as ''Ishq'' in [[Pakistan]]). The album topped the music charts in Pakistan as well as in the [[Persian Gulf]] and [[South Asia]]. The first single entitled "Zamanae Ke Andaz (Saqi-Nama)" made it to #1 in the Persian Gulf and to #5 on the Asian charts. In April, Junoon performed to a sold out concert at the [[Wembley Arena]] in London and went on to perform at the "United for Gujrat" concert, the first South Asian rock concert, held in [[New Delhi]] along with bands from [[India]] and [[Bangladesh]], singing together to raise funds for the Gujrat Earthquake victims. In June, [[Salman Ahmad]] attended the UN General Assembly in [[New York]] where he was appointed as the 'Goodwill Ambassador' of Pakistan by [[United Nations]].[http://www.unaids.org/en/partnerships/advocacy+partners/specrep/unaids_specialrep_salmanahmad.asp Salman Ahmad, Pakistan] Retrieved on July 16, 2010. On June 30, Junoon performed at the [[Celebrate Brooklyn]] festival at Prospect Park Bandshell in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York]]. On July 7, the band performed at the [[Hyatt Regency]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]. In September, Junoon did a concert in [[Norway]] with [[Morten Harket]], lead vocalist of [[A-ha]],[http://a-ha.com/news/articles/morten-guest-artist-with-the-pakistani-band-junoon/ Morten guest artist with the Pakistani band Junoon] Retrieved on July 16, 2010. performing a duet "Piya (Ocean of Love)".[http://a-ha.com/news/articles/junoon-rehearsing-with-morten-for-concert-on-september-5-in-oslo/ Junoon Rehearsing with Morten for concert on September 5th in Oslo] Retrieved on July 16, 2010.[http://www.btinternet.com/~darsu/discography/mharket/othermh.htm Morten Harket Side Projects] Retrieved on July 16, 2010.[http://a-ha.com/news/articles/musical-bridge-in-oslo/ Musical bridge in Oslo] Retrieved on July 16, 2010. The same year, the band also made a trip [[People's Republic of China|China]] to perform a peace concert. Following the terrorist attacks on [[September 11, 2001]], Junoon, in the aftermath of the attacks, traveled to the United States for a series of shows at universities and high schools. On October 9, the band played a peace concert at the United Nations (UN). On November 29, the music television channel, [[VH1]], aired a special doucmentary, ''[[Islamabad: Rock City]]'', about the group hosted by [[Susan Sarandon]].[http://www.prnewswire.com.au/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/11-26-2001/0001621860&EDATE= 'VH1 News Special: Islamabad Rock City'] Retrieved on July 21, 2010.[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0308418/ Islamabad: Rock City (2001)] Retrieved on July 21, 2010. On December 25, Junoon had once again been embraced by the Pakistani government, and were even joined on stage by then the President, [[General Pervez Musharraf]], as he invited them to perform at the mausoleum of Pakistan's founder, [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]], on Jinnah's birthday. Although Junoon continues to promote peace and harmony, the band also speaks out on contentious issues that most popular groups avoid. The band served as goodwill ambassadors for HIV/AIDS awareness for the UN and raised several issues. In 2002, Junoon opened a new chapter by releasing the antiterrorism song "No More" in English, yet another attempt by the group to spread their message to a wider audience.[http://www.rewaj.com/entertainment/the-third-generation-takes-over-2003-the-year-in-music.html The third generation takes over: 2003 â The year in music] Retrieved on April 19, 2011. Although, Junoon had previously released English songs on their first two albums, such as "Our Land", "Lady Magic", "Downtown Princes" and "Game Of Chance". The song "No More" is the first English song for which Junoon released a [[music video]].{{cite web|url=http://www.paknews.com/headingNews.php?id=1635&date1=2002-10-24|title=Junoon Brings 9/11 Song to America|accessdate=2009-06-05|publisher=paknews.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.junoon.com/articles/art_09.html|title=Junoon Rocks for Peace|accessdate=2009-06-05|publisher=Junoon.com}}[[File:Junoon-liveatwebster.jpg|thumb|right|250px| Junoon performing live at [[Webster Hall]], [[New York City]], on June 6, 2004. Visible from left to right are; vocalist [[Ali Azmat]] and lead guitarist [[Salman Ahmad]].]] [[CNN]] aired a 30 minute interview of Junoon on the program Talk Asia. They received rave reviews in ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard Magazine]]'', ''[[The New York Post]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', and others.[http://www.nytimes.com/2003/07/17/arts/television-review-a-rock-star-s-struggle-where-militant-islam-rules.html?scp=3&sq=Junoon&st=cse Review; A Rock Star's Struggle Where Militant Islam Rules] Retrieved on May 18, 2009[http://www.newsweek.com/id/76220 Band Fights Extremism] Retrieved on May 18, 2009 On March 29, Junoon released their second live album and the overall twelfth album, ''[[Daur-e-Junoon]]''.[http://www.pakipop.com/evaluation/daur_e_junoon.html Evaluation - Daur-e-Junoon] Retrieved on July 27, 2010 On February 16, 2003, Junoon performed at the Basant Festival Show held in [[Lahore]]. On May, 5, the band went to [[Karachi]] to perform at the PAF Creek Club. On June 18, Junoon performed live at the [[Royal Albert Hall]], [[London]], [[England]]. On July, 17, the documentary ''[[The Rock Star and the Mullahs]]'' by [[Wide Angle (TV series)|Wide Angel]] was aired on [[BBC]] based upon Junoon and music in Islam.[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0934348/ "Wide Angle" The Rock Star and the Mullas (2003)] Retrieved on July 16, 2010.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcfour/documentaries/storyville/rock-star.shtml The Rock Star & The Mullahs] Retrieved on July 16, 2010. In December, Junoon released their seventh studio album, ''[[Dewaar]]''.[http://www.junoon.com/articles/art_28.html; Dewaar Review] Retrieved on May 18, 2009[http://www.rewaj.com/entertainment/back-to-junooni-style.html Back to Junooni style] Retrieved on April 17, 2011. The single "[[Garaj Baras]]" was selected as the soundtrack of the [[Bollywood]] movie ''[[Paap]]'' directed by [[Pooja Bhatt]],[http://www.planetbollywood.com/Music/Paap/ Paap Soundtrack Review] Retrieved on July 16, 2010. the song topped the charts in the country again in 2004. Another single off the album "Pappu Yaar" shot to the #1 spot on the music charts in Pakistan. This was the album which last featured the trio together. After the release of the band's seventh studio album bassist, [[Brian O'Connell (musician)|Brian O'Connell]] went back to [[United States]] and vocalist, [[Ali Azmat]] went on to pursue his career as a solo singer. In April 2004, Junoon released their third compilation album, ''[[Dewaar: The Best of Junoon]]''. In August, Junoon released ''[[Ghoom Taana]]'' video and a special documentary entitled "Building Bridges" which was screened at a launch ceremony in [[Karachi]] in time for the Independence Day celebrations of [[Pakistan]] and [[India]]. On October 14, [[Journeyman Pictures]] released a short film documentary based on [[Pakistani music]] featuring local rock bands, Junoon and [[FuzÃ¶n]].[http://www.journeyman.tv/17702/short-films/rocking-the-system.html] Retrieved on March 20, 2010 ===Breakup (2005â2008)=== ''[[Dewaar]]'' was the album which last featured the trio together. After the release of the album [[Brian O'Connell (musician)|Brian O'Connell]] went back to United States.[http://www.pakipop.com/reflection/brian.html My Position in Junoon is Temporarily Non-existent] Retrieved on July 27, 2010. Since his departure, Pakistani musician [[Mekaal Hasan]] and the band's producer John Alec have been playing bass guitar for live shows in place. On February 2, 2005, Junoon performed a charity concert for the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami victims]] at [[Alhamra Arts Council|Alhamra Auditorium]] in [[Lahore]]. On March 3, Salman Ahmad appeared on the documentary ''[[It's My Country Too: Muslim Americans]]'' aired on [[BBC television]] [[documentary film|documentary]] strand [[This World (television programme)|This World]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/this_world/4340611.stm It's My Country Too] Retrieved on July 27, 2010 The last Junoon concert to feature [[Ali Azmat]] took place in [[Dubai]], [[UAE]] in March 2005 after which Ali Azmat went on to pursue his career as a solo singer.[http://www.rewaj.com/entertainment/ali-azmat-explains-going-solo.html Ali Azmat Explains Going Solo] Retrieved on April 19, 2011. Later the same year, he released his debut solo album, ''[[Social Circus (album)|Social Circus]]''.[http://www.pakipop.com/evaluation/social_circus.html Social Circus Review] Retrieved on July 25, 2010.[http://www.pakipop.com/reflection/social_animal.html Social Animal] Retrieved on July 25, 2010.[http://www.rewaj.com/entertainment/ali-azmat-launches-first-solo-album.html Social Circus: Ali Azmat launches first solo album] Retrieved on April 17, 2011. Shehryar Ahmad, the band manager also departed from the band. The song is based on a poem by musician, lyricist and journalist, Polar Levine. }} ===Language=== On their debut album ''[[Junoon (Junoon album)|Junoon]]'' and their second album ''[[Talaash]]'', songs were written in both the English and Urdu languages, but since then the band has only written songs in Urdu, with the only exceptions being "No More" from the live album ''[[Junoon for Peace]]'' and the single "Piya (Ocean of Love)", which is a duet with [[Morten Harket]] of [[A-ha]]. The soundtrack album ''[[Rock & Roll Jihad]]'' released in 2010 contain five tracks written in English by [[Salman Ahmad]]. ===Influence=== [[Salman Ahmad]], writer of most of the band's lyrics and [[Sheet music|music scores]], says that he gets most of his inspiration for Junoon's songs from [[Led Zeppelin]] and [[Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan]] music. Songs like "Lal Meri Pat" (from ''[[Azadi (album)|Azadi]]''), "Dharti" (from ''[[Andaz (album)|Andaz]]'') and "Mera Mahi" (from ''[[Inquilaab]]'') are some examples of this influence. Other songs, such as "[[Garaj Baras]]" and "Taara Jala" (from ''[[Dewaar]]'') have elements of [[hard rock]],[http://www.eomag.com/reviews/music/junoon_deewar.htm Junoon Dewaar review] Retrieved on June 4, 2010 and some others, like "[[Yaar Bina]]" (from ''Azadi''), "Zamane Ke Andaz" (from ''Andaz'') and the album ''[[Parvaaz]]'' have elements of [[classical music]]. Bands stated as influence include Led Zeppelin, [[Pink Floyd]], [[Van Halen]], [[U2]], [[Bee Gees]], [[A-ha]] and [[Queen (band)|Queen]]. Poetry by famous poets like [[Rumi|Maulana Rumi]], [[Allama Iqbal]] and [[Bulleh Shah]] are also a big influence on Junoon's music.{{cite news | first=Jon | last=Pareles | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Pop Review| date=11 August 1998 | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/11/arts/pop-review-moving-the-spirit-and-feet-with-ancient-utterances-updated.html?n=Top%2FReference%2FTimes%20Topics%2FSubjects%2FC%2FCentral%20Park%20Summerstage&scp=10&sq=Junoon&st=cse| work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-05-14 | language = }}{{cite news | first=Jon | last=Pareles | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=In Performance| date= May 2002 | publisher=[[The New York Times]] | url =http://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/08/arts/in-performance-pop-divine-and-secular-love-expressed-in-rock-style.html?scp=7&sq=Junoon&st=cse| work = | pages = | accessdate = 2009-05-19 | language = }} The album ''Parvaaz'' is a tribute album to Bulleh Shah and is mostly based on Bulleh Shah's poetry. The songs "Zamane Ke Andaz", from the album ''Andaz'', and "Khudi", from the album ''Azadi'', are poems by Allama Iqbal. On the other hand, Junoon has also been noted as a source of inspiration for other bands. The single also featured as a soundtrack of the Bollywood movie ''[[Paap]]'' directed by [[Pooja Bhatt]]. }} Junoon performs a blend of western music and classical eastern poetry. Junoon aimed to combine loud guitar riffs with the tranquility of sufi poetry by the likes of [[Rumi|Maulana Rumi]], [[Shah Hussain]], [[Bulleh Shah]] and [[Allama Iqbal]]. Their music has been based on worldly issues and to have peace in the world. Their music has been one major force which has truly kept the national spirits high amidst the prevailing social woes which have surely worsened in the last three decades. Songs like "[[Jazba-e-Junoon]]", "[[Talaash (song)|Talaash]]", "Main Kaun Hoon" and "[[Sayonee]]" are examples. Their music has been captivating to the Pakistani youth for over ten years and have been the only saving grace of Pakistani music internationally after the departure of groups like [[Vital Signs (band)|Vital Signs]] and [[Nazia and Zoheb]].New York Times, 28-11-1997, [http://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/28/movies/pop-and-jazz-guide-344290.html?scp=6&sq=Junoon&st=cse Pop and Jazz Guide] Retrieved on May 18, 2009 Junoon's music has also been compared by some critics with the likes of [[Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan]] and [[Lata Mangeshkar]]. While the music of Junoon is centered around a male lead singer, the band has also featured some female vocals on their albums ever since their self-titled debut release ''[[Junoon (Junoon album)|Junoon]]''. Since the release of their third studio album ''[[Inquilaab]]'' the band's music has been based on classical eastern poetry blending with western music. Their seventh studio album ''[[Dewaar]]'' featured elements of [[hard rock]] music with songs like "[[Garaj Baras]]" and "Dewaar".[http://www.pakipop.com/evaluation/dewaar.html Evaluation - Dewaar] Retrieved on July 27, 2010 ===Live performances=== As the band started to gain success after the release of their third studio album ''[[Inquilaab]]'', Junoon went on their first full scale tour of the [[United States]], performing from [[Birmingham, Alabama]], to [[Los Angeles]] where the appeared at the [[House of Blues]] and from there to [[Roosevelt Hotel (New York)|New York's Roosevelt Hotel]], which featured in ''[[Newsweek Magazine]]''. [[File:Junoonthree.jpg|thumb|left|250px| Junoon performing live at the [[Channel V|Channel V Music Awards]] in 1998.]]During the tour to [[India]] in 1997, Junoon saw crowds of as many as of 50,000 fans at different venues. The band was courted for a controversy during their tour to India by the Pakistani government. The Indian government was testing nuclear devices at that time, and [[Salman Ahmad]] suggested that the Indian and Pakistani leaders should spend more on education and health and less on weapons. This led to a prolonged ban on Junoon's music by the Pakistani government. [[Pakistan Television Corporation|PTV]], the Pakistan state television, refused to show the audience even clips from Junoon releases. Junoon also became the first band ever to perform at an UN conference when they performed their Millennium Peace concert held in [[Paris]], [[France]]. For their performances they were presented with an award, "Outstanding Achievements in Music and Peace", by [[UNESCO]]. One of the most popular concerts that Junoon performed was their tour to [[Denmark]] and [[Europe]] in 2000-2001. This tour played a pivotal role in increasing Junoon's international popularity and standing and in spreading awareness about [[Pakistani music]]. During their tour to Denmark they became the first Asian band to perform at the [[Roskilde Festival]] along with many well known bands and musicians like [[Pearl Jam]], [[Iron Maiden]], [[The Cure]], [[QueensrÃ¿che]] and many other well known artists from around the world. On September 5, 2001, Junoon performed in [[Norway]] with Morten Harket of A-ha as they performed a duet, "Piya (Ocean of Love)", at the [[Oslo Spektrum]] which attracted a crowd of about 3000 people. ==Awards and nominations== {{Main|List of awards and nominations received by Junoon}} Junoon won the "Best International Group" award at the [[Channel V|Channel V Awards]] in 1998.
